Detailed Description

An immutable time stamp.



For time values (i.e. the integer time mode is not None or Other), there are four different "epochs" that are supported by this class (see below); however all time values stored within this class will be in UTC or GPS time.

UTC (per VITA-49 specification)

This measures number of 1-second clock tics since 1 JAN 1970. Note that the VITA-49 specification is extremely clear on the point that this includes leap seconds.

This class makes the assumption that only times after 1 JAN 1972 (or zero) are used. This is important since prior to 1 JAN 1972 the duration of 1 UTC second differed from the definition used today (since 1 JAN 1972 the duration of 1 UTC second matches the SI, TAI, and GPS definitions). It is also assumed that exactly 11 leap seconds took place between 1 JAN 1970 and 6 JAN 1980. This "11 leap second" assumption is consistent with the example provided in IEEE 1588-2008 (see section B.2 of [2]) that shows an 8 leap-second difference between UTC and TAI on 1 Jan 1970 and the officially-accepted 19 leap-second difference between UTC and TAI on 1 Jan 1980 (see [4]). 

    1:  LS  = (Leap Seconds Added Between 1 Jan 1970 to 6 Jan 1980)
    2:  LS  = (Leap Seconds 1 Jan 1970 to 1 Jan 1980) + (Leap Seconds 1 Jan 1980 to 6 Jan 1980)
    3:  LS  = (Leap Seconds 1 Jan 1970 to 1 Jan 1980) +               0
    3:  LS  = (Leap Seconds 1 Jan 1970 to 1 Jan 1980)
    4:  LS  = (Total Leap Seconds on 1 Jan 1980) - (Total Leap Seconds on 1 Jan 1970)
    5:  LS  =                 19                 - (Total Leap Seconds on 1 Jan 1970)
    6:  LS  =                 19                 -                  8
    7:  LS  =                                    11
   3 - by definition no leap seconds are added mid-month
   4 - basic expansion
   5 - per USNO, see [4]
   6 - per IEEE 1588-2008, see [2]

Although UTC time includes leap seconds. The number of leap seconds elapsed must still be looked up every time a conversion is made to another time format and/or a time string (year-month-day).

GPS (per VITA-49 specification)

This measures number of 1-second clock tics since 6 JAN 1980. In practice, this is usually the most efficient form to use as there is never a need to worry about leap second adjustments.

POSIX (in seconds since start of epoch)

The POSIX time is extremely common on most computers, but it is extremely ill-defined. Many sources say that POSIX time is equal to UTC time, but (especially when represented in seconds-since-epoch form) that is simply not true. The true POSIX epoch is equal to: 

    POSIX Seconds    =    (days since 1 Jan 1970) * (86,400 sec/day) + (seconds of current day)

Note that the above equation differs from UTC time in that, UTC time is not fixed at 86,400 sec/day, but rather can be 86,399 sec/day (subtract a leap second), 86,400 sec/day (normal), or 86,401 sec/day (add a leap second). This implicitly yields: 

    POSIX Seconds    =    (days since 1 Jan 1970) * (86,400 sec/day) + (seconds of current day)
                     =    (UTC seconds since 1 JAN 1970) - (UTC leap-seconds since 1 JAN 1970)

When a POSIX time it converted to a string (i.e. year-month-day hours:min:sec) it will match the string for a UTC time ~99.9996% of the time -- this is why people say it is equal to UTC. Anyone who cares about precision time should be immediately concerned about the ~0.0004% of the time where it is just plain wrong (~0.0004% matches the 12 times of the year where a leap-second can be added/removed).

The most problematic thing with POSIX time is that it contains no information about the number of leap-seconds that it didn't count. This means that it is impossible to determine the correct time when at the point of a leap-second insertion and means that basic math on the times won't suffice to determine the number UTC seconds elapsed between two POSIX time stamps.

There is a discontinuity in the POSIX time epoch at the point where a leap-second is added/removed. This class makes no guarantees with regards to the behavior at the point of the discontinuity and may report the time immediately before or immediately after the discontinuity (plus any fractional seconds).

Midas (in seconds since start of epoch)



Midas time is effectively identical to POSIX time but with an epoch starting at 1 Jan 1950, and with fractional seconds represented as a fraction rather than the number of picoseconds. 

    Midas Seconds    =    (days since 1 Jan 1950) * (86,400 sec/day) + (seconds of current day)
                     =    (POSIX Seconds) + (seconds between 1 Jan 1950 and 1 Jan 1970)
                     =    (POSIX Seconds) + MIDAS2POSIX

All conversions to/from Midas time involve an intermediate conversion to/from POSIX time and are subject to the same issues with respect to leap-seconds.

The conversion to/from fractional seconds as used in Midas time and picoseconds is simply done using the following equation: 

    Fractional Sec   =    (number of picoseconds) / (picoseconds in one second)
                     =    (number of picoseconds) / ONE_SEC

NORAD/IRIG (in seconds since start of current year)

NORAD time is a fairly common one to use, particularly for aerospace-based applications. NORAD time measures the number of seconds since the start of the current UTC year. IRIG time measures day-of-year and seconds-of-day (which effectively equates to seconds-of-year after multiplying day-of-year by 86,400 sec/day). 

     +------------------------+-----------+-------------+
     |      TIME-OF-YEAR      |  CONTROL  | TIME-OF-DAY |
     | SEC | MIN | HRS | DAYS | FUNCTIONS |  (seconds)  |
     +-----+-----+-----+------+-----------+-------------+
     |     |     |     |      |           |             |
     +-----+-----+-----+------+-----------+-------------+
                    IRIG Format B (see [1])
      +------------------------------------+-----------+
      |              TIME-OF-YEAR          |  CONTROL  |
      | SEC | MIN | HRS | DAYS | 1/100 SEC | FUNCTIONS |
      +-----+-----+-----+------+-----------+-----------+
      |     |     |     |      |           |           |
      +-----+-----+-----+------+-----------+-----------+
                    IRIG Format G (see [1])

Unfortunately the NORAD definition is some-what ambiguous as to how mid-year leap-seconds are handled, while IRIG is ambiguous in application. This leads to two possible definitions for NORAD (and IRIG-based) time: 

    NORAD Seconds    =    (UTC seconds since start of current year)
                  -- OR --
    NORAD Seconds    =    (POSIX seconds since start of current year)
                     =    ((day of year - 1) * (86,400 sec/day)) + (seconds of current day)           [= IRIG B]
                     =    ((day of year - 1) * (86,400 sec/day)) + ((hr * 3600) + (min * 60) + sec)   [= IRIG B/G]
                     =    (UTC seconds since start of current year) - (mid-year leap-seconds)

IRIG time, as reported, follows the second definition (though it is unclear how the 61st second is to be reported during a leap-second addition, see section 2.6 of [1]). The issue with IRIG time is that devices reading the IRIG time will be able to detect the leap second but will not be able to discern that a mid-year leap-second has taken place by exclusively looking at the IRIG time reported subsequent to the leap-second addition.

As of current (Jan 2012), it has been 14+ years since the last mid-year leap second, so there is little reason to believe that past experience will be a good behavior of future behavior (14 years being longer than the life-cycle of most equipment.) It fact, it is well-known that a number of recently-produced devices that read IRIG time and produce a NORAD/UTC time-stamp differ with regards to their implementation. Accordingly, the NORAD-/IRIG-centric functions permit the specification of which form to use, and also allow a default to be set at run-time (see VRTConfig).

One of the inherent issues with using NORAD/IRIG time is that it is necessary to separately provide an indication as to the relevant year. The functions in this class that support a NORAD to UTC conversion allow the the year to be specified. If the year is given as -1, the following algorithm is used to derive the year from the local system clock:

  • The current year is taken from the local system clock, which is presumed to be approximate enough to estimate the current year within a couple days
  • If a late-December NORAD time is seen in early-January, the previous year is used
  • If an early-January NORAD time is seen in late-December, the subsequent year is used
  • Otherwise the current year is used

The above algorithm gives a few days leeway to account for cases where data that is time-stamped at the end of one year (e.g. 31 DEC) does not get processed until the beginning of the next year (e.g. 1 JAN). It also gives allowances for the local system to be approximate-at-best rather than being locked to a stable time source; and for the local system time to be using POSIX time where an end-of-year leap second gives rise to some ambiguity (see above).

If the second definition is used, there will be a discontinuity in the NORAD time epoch at the point where a leap-second is added/removed. This class makes no guarantees with regards to the behavior at the point of the discontinuity and may report the time immediately before or immediately after the discontinuity (plus any fractional seconds).

Precision Time Protocol (PTP)



PTP is an IEEE standard (see [2]) for clock synchronization among computing devices for situations where "precision" time is required but where the (direct or indirect) cost of a GPS receiver is prohibitive.

PTP provides seconds and nanoseconds referenced to 1 Jan 1970 TAI which differs from 1 Jan 1970 UTC by 8 seconds (see section B.2 of [2]). PTP counts TAI seconds (which are identical to GPS seconds) and has a fixed reference to GPS time (see section 5.3.3 and Table B.1 of [2]): 

    GPS Seconds = PTP Seconds - 315,964,819 seconds


Only a basic conversion from PTP is provided. Although it would be viable to include a PTP reader that connects to the applicable sockets, it is currently outside the scope of this library.

HasFields

The following implementation is used for the HasFields methods, but note that since the TimeStamp is immutable they are read-only: 

     ID | Name                 | Type
    ----+----------------------+---------------
      0 | String               | String
      1 | StringUTC            | String
      2 | StringGPS            | String
      3 | Epoch                | Int8
      4 | IntegerMode          | Int8
      5 | FractionalMode       | Int8
      6 | UTCSeconds           | Int64
      7 | GPSSeconds           | Int64
      8 | NORADSeconds         | Int64
      9 | POSIXSeconds         | Int64
     10 | MidasTime            | Double
     11 | MidasSeconds         | Double
     12 | PicoSeconds          | Int64
     13 | FractionalSeconds    | Double
     14 | TimeStampInteger     | Int64
     15 | TimeStampFractional  | Int64
    ----+----------------------+---------------


References

     [1] Timing Committee / Range Commanders Council / Telecommunications and Timing
         Group. "IRIG Serial Time Code Formats." IRIG Standard 200-98. Secretariat,
         Range Commanders Council, U.S. Army White Sands Missile Range Pub. May 1998.
     [2] IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Society. "IEEE Standard for a Precision
         Clock Synchronization Protocol for Networked Measurement and Control Systems."
         IEEE Std 1588-2008. The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers,
         Inc. 24 July 2008.
     [3] USNO. "Leap Seconds." Time Service Dept., U.S. Naval Observatory.
         http://tycho.usno.navy.mil/leapsec.html Last Accessed 15 September 2011.
         (Note: The companion to this is [4].)
     [4] USNO. "tai-utc.dat" Time Service Dept., U.S. Naval Observatory.
         http://maia.usno.navy.mil/ser7/tai-utc.dat or
         ftp://maia.usno.navy.mil/ser7/tai-utc.dat Last Accessed 19 January 2012.
         (Note: This is the same file used by the LeapSeconds class and
         is alternately titled "tai_utc_data.txt" by some systems. It is also
         described in Appendix D of [5].)
     [5] Klyne, G., C. Newman. "Date and Time on the Internet: Timestamps." Network
         Working Group. RFC3339. July 2002.

References addTime().

TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::addTime ( int64_t  sec,
int64_t  ps 
) const [inline]

Adds the specified number of picoseconds to the current time and returns the resulting time. 

    r = t.addTime(sec, ps)
    implies: r.getTimeStampInteger()    = t.getTimeStampInteger()    + sec
             r.getTimeStampFractional() = t.getTimeStampFractional() + ps

Note that if the value of ps exceeds ONE_SEC, the input parameters will be normalized with: 

    sec = (ps / ONE_SEC) + sec;
    ps  = (ps % ONE_SEC);

Note that subtracting time can be accomplished simply by calling addTime(-sec,-ps). Both sec and ps must be signed negative to accomplish the subtraction of seconds+picoseconds.

This method maintains the functionality that the following will all of the following are equal (assuming time never exceeds 0xFFFFFFFF, not drops below the start of the epoch): 

    r = t.addTime(a,b)
    r = t.addTime(a,0L).addTime(0L,b)
    r = t.addTime(0L,b).addTime(a,0L)
Parameters:
sec The number of seconds.
ps The number of picoseconds.
Returns:
A new time object representing the resulting time.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the getIntegerMode() is not IntegerMode_UTC or IntegerMode_GPS or if getFractionalMode() is not FractionalMode_RealTime.

References ONE_SEC.

Referenced by addPicoSeconds(), addSamples(), and addSeconds().

char vrt::TimeStamp::compareTo ( const TimeStamp &  other  )  const

Compares time stamp values.

If the time stamps have different epochs, this method will attempt to convert both to GPS and will throw a VRTException if unable to do so. If the fractional time stamp values have a different reference, an VRTException will be thrown. This method assumes that any "wrap-arround" within the fractional time stamp is accounted for in the integral time stamp. If two GPS/UTC times are compared, this will return 0 iff they represent exactly the same instant in time.

Returns:
<0 if this is comes before than other, =0 if this is comes at the same point as other, >0 if this is comes after than other.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the current time stamp is not GPS or UTC.
bool vrt::TimeStamp::equals ( const VRTObject &  ts  )  const

Equals method that checks for strict equality.

Two time stamps representing the same point but using different epoch (UTC vs GPS) will not be considered equal.

Parameters:
ts The object to compare to this one.
Returns:
true if exactly equal, false otherwise.

int64_t  picoseconds,
int32_t  year,
LeapSeconds *  _ls

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeIRIG ( int32_t  seconds,
int32_t  minutes,
int32_t  hours,
int32_t  days,
int32_t  hundreths,
LeapSeconds *  ls 
) [static]

Creates a time stamp from an IRIG time.

This function implicitly knows that IRIG time does not indicate if any mid-year leap-seconds that have occurred nor does it count them (except in rare situations that the IRIG time stamp is seen as a leap-second is being added [i.e. 23:59:60], in which case this function returns forTimeIRIG(59,59,23,days,hundreths,ls).addSeconds(1)); as such, it always consults the applicable leap-seconds table to check for scheduled mid-year leap-seconds.

Parameters:
seconds The number of whole seconds since the start of the minute (0 to 59[+1]).
minutes The number of whole minutes since the start of the hour (0 to 59).
hours The number of whole hours since the start of the day (0 to 23).
days The number of whole days since the start of the year (0 to 365[+1]) where 1=Jan1, 2=Jan2, ..., 32=Feb1, ...).
hundreths The number of whole 1/100 seconds since the start of the current second (0 to 99).
ls The leap seconds instance to use.
Returns:
The corresponding TimeStamp.
Exceptions:
IllegalArgumentException If an invalid parameter is specified.
static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeIRIG ( int32_t  seconds,
int32_t  minutes,
int32_t  hours,
int32_t  days,
int32_t  hundreths 
) [inline, static]

Creates a time stamp from an IRIG time.

This is the same as forTimeIRIG(seconds,minutes,hours,days,hundreths,LeapSeconds::getDefaultInstance())

Parameters:
seconds The number of whole seconds since the start of the minute (0 to 59[+1]).
minutes The number of whole minutes since the start of the hour (0 to 59).
hours The number of whole hours since the start of the day (0 to 23).
days The number of whole days since the start of the year (0 to 365[+1]) where 1=Jan1, 2=Jan2, ..., 32=Feb1, ...).
hundreths The number of whole 1/100 seconds since the start of the current second (0 to 99).
Returns:
The corresponding TimeStamp.
Exceptions:
IllegalArgumentException If an invalid parameter is specified.

References forTimeIRIG(), and vrt::LeapSeconds::getDefaultInstance().

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeMidas ( double  seconds,
double  fractionalSeconds,

) [inline, static]

Creates a time stamp from a Midas time.

This is identical to: 

    forTimePOSIX(seconds - MIDAS2POSIX, ONE_SEC * fractionalSeconds, ls)

WARNING: seconds must be an integral value and fractionalSeconds must be a value on the range [0,1). Failure to follow this will result in undefined behavior.

Parameters:

fractionalSeconds The fractional seconds since the start of the current second.
_ls The leap seconds instance to use (null to use default).
Returns:
The corresponding TimeStamp.
Exceptions:
VRTException if the time corresponds to a value prior to 1972/01/01.

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeNORAD ( int32_t  seconds,
int64_t  picoseconds,
boolNull  leapCounted,
int32_t  year,
LeapSeconds *  _ls 
) [inline, static]

Creates a time stamp from a NORAD time.

The NORAD time epoch is measured in number of 1-second intervals elapsed since the start of the current UTC year; however, there is some ambiguity as to whether a mid-year leap second is counted or not counted. At the time this function was written (2011), it had been 14+ years since the last mid-year leap second, so there is little reason to believe that past experience in this regard is a good indicator of future behavior.

Automatic Year Setting: When converting NORAD time to UTC, the number of UTC seconds at the start of the current year is added in. If the year is not given (i.e. -1), the current year is used. However, if a late-December time is seen in early-January, the previous year is used. Similarly if an early-January time is seen in late-December, the subsequent year is used. This is done to account for cases where data that is time-stamped at the end of one year does not get processed until the beginning of the next year.

Parameters:
seconds The number of whole seconds since the start of the year.
picoseconds The number of picoseconds since the start of the current second.
leapCounted Were any mid-year leap seconds counted (true) or skipped (false)? If this is _NULL, the value of VRTConfig::getNoradLeapSecCounted() is used.
year The year to use (-1 for automatic, otherwise after 1972).
_ls The leap seconds instance to use.
Returns:
The corresponding TimeStamp.

References vrt::VRTConfig::getNoradLeapSecCounted().

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeNORAD ( int32_t  seconds,
int64_t  picoseconds,
int32_t  year,
LeapSeconds *  _ls 
) [inline, static]

Creates a time stamp from a NORAD time.

The NORAD time epoch is measured in number of 1-second intervals elapsed since the start of the current UTC year; however, there is some ambiguity as to whether a mid-year leap second is counted or not counted. This is the same as forTimeNORAD(seconds, picoseconds, _NULL, year, ls)

Parameters:
seconds The number of whole seconds since the start of the year.
picoseconds The number of picoseconds since the start of the current second.
year The year to use (-1 for automatic, otherwise after 1972).
_ls The leap seconds instance to use.
Returns:
The corresponding TimeStamp.

References forTimeNORAD().

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::forTimePTP ( int64_t  seconds,
int64_t  nanoseconds,
LeapSeconds *  _ls 
) [inline, static]

Creates a GPS time stamp from a PTP time.

This only supports times after 6 Jan 1980 since there is a simple conversion from PTP to GPS time. It is possible to convert from PTP to UTC for dates between 1 Jan 1972 (not 1 Jan 1970) and 6 Jan 1980, but it would add significant complication to what is otherwise a trivial function that the compiler can easily in-line.

Parameters:
seconds The number of whole seconds since the PTP epoch.
nanoseconds The number of nanoseconds since the start of the current second.
_ls The leap seconds instance to use.
Returns:
The corresponding TimeStamp.
Exceptions:
VRTException if the time corresponds to a value prior to 1980/01/06.

References GPS2PTP, and TimeStamp().

int64_t  nanoseconds 
) [inline, static]

It is possible to convert from PTP to UTC for dates between 1 Jan 1972 (not 1 Jan 1970) and 6 Jan 1980, but it would add significant complication to what is otherwise a trivial function that the compiler can easily in-line.

Parameters:

nanoseconds The number of nanoseconds since the start of the current second.

Reimplemented from vrt::HasFields.

virtual string vrt::TimeStamp::getFieldName ( int32_t  id  )  const [virtual]

Gets the name of the given field.

In 90% of cases the field name will be identical to the name used in the applicable get/set function except without the get/set prefix (e.g. "SourceContext" for "getSourceContext"). It is possible to access the names of all fields via the following: 

    for (int32_t id = 0; id < getFieldCount(); id++) {
      // id is the field ID
      getFieldName(id);
    }

In situations where it is desirable to access all available fields, it is faster to use the field ID as this eliminates any string comparisons.

Parameters:
id The field ID (on range [0,getFieldCount())).
Returns:
The field name.
Exceptions:
VRTException if the field id is invalid.

Reimplemented from vrt::HasFields.

virtual ValueType vrt::TimeStamp::getFieldType ( int32_t  id  )  const [virtual]

Gets the type associated with a given field.

Parameters:
id The field ID (on range [0,getFieldCount())).
Returns:
The field type (n > 0) or -N if the field is a vector of values where N is the component type of the vector.

Reimplemented from vrt::HasFields.

double vrt::TimeStamp::getMidasTime (  )  const [inline]

Gets the integer and fractional time stamp in Midas seconds.

This is identical to: 

     getMidasSeconds() + getFractionalSeconds()    // using RealTime
    or
     getMidasSeconds()                             // not using RealTime

WARNING: This will result in a loss of precision! Users are advised to use getMidasSeconds and getFractionalSeconds to avoid this loss of precision.

Returns:
The integer and fractional time stamp with some loss of precision.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the time stamp is not GPS or UTC.
See also:
getSecondsPOSIX()

References getFractionalMode(), getFractionalSeconds(), and getMidasSeconds().

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::getSystemTime ( LeapSeconds *  ls  )  [static]

Gets a time stamp using system time.

This time should be considered unreliable as it is using gettimeofday(..) as its data source rather than a precision time reference. The resolution of this time stamp is only as good as that provided by the O/S, and will never be better than 1 micorsecond.

Parameters:
ls The leap-seconds reference to use.
static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::getSystemTime (  )  [inline, static]

Gets a time stamp using system time.

This time should be considered unreliable as it is using gettimeofday(..) as its data source rather than a precision time reference. The resolution of this time stamp is only as good as that provided by the O/S, and will never be better than 1 micorsecond.

References vrt::LeapSeconds::getDefaultInstance().

static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::parseTime ( string  time,
IntegerMode  tsiMode,
LeapSeconds *  ls 
) [static]

Parses a time stamp in one of the following ISO 8601 formats. 

    yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss        (TimeZone = +0 hours)
    yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sssZ       (TimeZone = +0 hours)
    yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss+zz     (TimeZone = +zz hours)
    yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss-zz     (TimeZone = -zz hours)
    yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss+zz:zz  (TimeZone = +zz:zz hours)
    yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.sss-zz:zz  (TimeZone = -zz:zz hours)
Parameters:
time The time string.
tsiMode The time epoch (must be IntegerMode_GPS or IntegerMode_UTC).
ls The leap seconds instance to use.
Returns:
The parsed time stamp.
static TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::parseTime ( string  time,
IntegerMode  _tsiMode 
) [inline, static]

Parses a time stamp in one of the ISO 8601 formats documented in parseTime(time, tsiMode, ls).

Parameters:
time The time string.
_tsiMode The time epoch (must be IntegerMode_GPS or IntegerMode_UTC).
Returns:
The parsed time stamp.

TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::toGPS (  )  const

Converts from UTC or GPS time to GPS.

This operation does nothing to the fractional time seconds, and is only valid for dates after 1-Jan-1980.

Returns:
this if already in GPS, otherwise a new TimeStamp in UTC time representing the same time.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the current time stamp is not GPS or UTC.
string vrt::TimeStamp::toString (  )  const [virtual]

A textural representation of the time stamp.

If the integer mode is IntegerMode_GPS or IntegerMode_UTC and fractional mode is FractionalMode_None or FractionalMode_RealTime (i.e. the 90% use case) the output will be an RFC3339-compatible time stamp with 0 (no fractional time stamp) or 12 (picoseconds) decimal places followed by either " (GPS)" or " (UTC)". Other time stamps will use a custom format.

References: 

    Klyne, G. and C. Newman. "RFC3339 - Date and Time on the Internet: Timestamps."
    Network Working Group. July 2002. http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc3339.html
    (accessed 2009-07-31).
Returns:
A textural representation of the time stamp, or null if both IntegerMode and FractionalMode are None.

Reimplemented from vrt::VRTObject.

string vrt::TimeStamp::toStringGPS (  )  const

A textural representation of the time stamp in UTC.

This is identical to the time stamp produced by ts.toGPS().toString() except that the " (GPS)" suffix is omitted.

Returns:
A textural representation of the time stamp, or null if both IntegerMode and FractionalMode are None.
string vrt::TimeStamp::toStringUTC (  )  const

A textural representation of the time stamp in UTC.

This is identical to the time stamp produced by ts.toUTC().toString() except that the " (UTC)" suffix is omitted.

Returns:
A textural representation of the time stamp, or null if both IntegerMode and FractionalMode are None.
string vrt::TimeStamp::toStringUTC ( string  format  )  const

Internal Use Only (Experimental)

TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::toUTC (  )  const

Converts from UTC or GPS time to UTC.

This operation does nothing to the fractional time seconds, and is only valid for dates after 1-Jan-1980.

Returns:
this if already in UTC, otherwise a new TimeStamp in GPS time representing the same time.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the current time stamp is not GPS or UTC.

Member Data Documentation

const int32_t vrt::TimeStamp::GPS2PTP [static]

Delta between GPS and PTP epochs. 

    GPS2PTP = 315,964,819 seconds

Referenced by forTimePTP().

const int32_t vrt::TimeStamp::GPS2UTC [static]

Delta between GPS and UTC epochs. 

    GPS2UTC = (days 1 Jan 1970 to 6 Jan 1980) * (86,400 sec/day) + (leap seconds)
    GPS2UTC = (3,657 days) * (86,400 sec/day) + (11 seconds)
    GPS2UTC = 315,964,811 seconds

See top of class for a detailed discussion regarding number of leap seconds added between 1 Jan 1970 and 6 Jan 1980.

const IntegerMode vrt::TimeStamp::GPS_EPOCH [static]

The GPS epoch.

const double vrt::TimeStamp::HALF_PICOSECOND [static]

The value of 1/2 picosecond in seconds. 

    HALF_PICOSECOND = 0.500e-12 seconds
const int32_t vrt::TimeStamp::MIDAS2POSIX [static]

Delta between Midas and POSIX epochs. 

    MIDAS2POSIX = (days 1 Jan 1950 to 1 Jan 1970) * (86,400 sec/day)
    MIDAS2POSIX = 631,152,000 seconds

Referenced by forTimeMidas(), and getMidasSeconds().

const TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::NO_TIME_STAMP [static]

An empty time stamp.

This is equal to: 

    NO_TIME_STAMP = TimeStamp(IntegerMode.None, FractionalMode.None, null, null)
const IntegerMode vrt::TimeStamp::NULL_EPOCH [static]

The "null" epoch.

const double vrt::TimeStamp::ONE_PICOSECOND [static]

The value of 1 picosecond in seconds. 

    ONE_PICOSECOND = (1.0 / ONE_SEC) = 1e-12 seconds

Note that this is explicitly defined as 1e-12 rather than the division shown above to avoid rounding errors that may otherwise be introduced.

const int64_t vrt::TimeStamp::ONE_SEC [static]

The value of 1 second in picoseconds. 

    ONE_SEC = 1000000000000 picoseconds

Referenced by addPicoSeconds(), addSamples(), addTime(), forTimeMidas(), and getFractionalSeconds().

const uint64_t vrt::TimeStamp::ONE_SECOND [static]

The value of 1 second in picoseconds (unsigned variant). 

    ONE_SECOND = 1000000000000 picoseconds
const IntegerMode vrt::TimeStamp::UTC_EPOCH [static]

The UTC epoch.

const TimeStamp vrt::TimeStamp::Y2K_GPS [static]

This is equal to the start of the year 2000 in the GPS epoch and provides a reasonable minimum bounds for most time values.
